history.content:
If you're going to take 126, I would not recommend also taking 140 (redundancy in material). 

188 serves as a fair introduction to AI, but on its own is not sufficient for ML research. If you want to prepare yourself for ML research, 126 is a great start; EE127 is also a key class for AI/ML. If you feel confident in your mathematical maturity, you could go directly for 189, which is by far the best class for ML.

To answer your question directly, 188 > 140 (assuming 126 is in the mix); however, 127 > 188, and 126 + 127 would serve as a great combo. 

---

I'd like to second the existing answer in terms of taking 126 over 140. If you've taken CS70, much of stat140 is going to be review (and you said you did well in the probability, so it will be a waste of time to review for you). 126 gets to assume cs70 level probability, so it will get to cover more advanced probability/applications. cs188 is not a bad class, but if you're going into ML research you may want to look into 189 since 188 is not a real prereq for 189.

If you're going to take 126, I would not recommend also taking 140 (redundancy in material). 

188 serves as a fair introduction to AI, but on its own is not sufficient for ML research. If you want to prepare yourself for ML research, 126 is a great start; EE127 is also a key class for AI/ML. If you feel confident in your mathematical maturity, you could go directly for 189, which is by far the best class for ML.

To answer your question directly, 188 > 140 (assuming 126 is in the mix); however, 127 > 188, and 126 + 127 would serve as a great combo.

children.subject:
The thing is, if you want to do ML + RL(Reinforcement Learning) research, or ML + Robotics, 188 provides a good layer of understanding for reinforcement learning, Q-Learning, etc. Not saying you can't self-study it, but the class is honestly not too big a time investment, is quite fun, and definitely helps with the above areas.

Also 188 is really not much of a programming class - the projects are straightforward in terms of programming, so even if you're not as interested in that side of things, 188 isn't a bad idea.

A good idea is usually to take 188 as a third tech (it's light, interesting, and prepares you for RL), so 126 + 188 + 127 is actually amazing prep for 189 and ML research; if you're feeling bold enough to jump right in, 126 + 189 is certainly possible too given sufficient mathematical maturity (read Prof Sahai's answers in this piazza to get an idea of what that actually means)

Thank you! Would you recommend taking 188 at all? I'm not interested in programming so I don't think I would enjoy the Pacman projects too much. However, I looked at the slides and exams for 188 and found them to be challenging and interesting.

history.content:
Hi, 

I'm having a difficult time choosing between Stat 140 and CS 188. The lecture is at the same time so I can only take one of them, and I probably wouldn't take the other one in the future. Some context: I'm a sophomore intended CS/applied math double major, interested in probability / stats and did very well in probability part of CS70. I'm going to take EE126 and probably STAT135 in spring. I want to do ML related research in spring/summer. Will stat140 or CS188 prepare me better to ML research? 

Thanks!
history.subject: Stat 140 or CS188
